title: Graphical Analysis w Int by Parts and Improper Int

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, the derivative of the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, is shown above for <math alttext="negative 1 less than x, less than 10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis, and the vertical line <math alttext="x equals 9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="g of 0 equals negative 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g of 9 equals 20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 9, of, g of x, d x, equals 39.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>39.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find all values of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="negative 1 is less than x, is less than 10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, if any, at which <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a critical point. Classify each critical point as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither. Justify your answers.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, the derivative of the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, is shown above for <math alttext="negative 1 less than x, less than 10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis, and the vertical line <math alttext="x equals 9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="g of 0 equals negative 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g of 9 equals 20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 9, of, g of x, d x, equals 39.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>39.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find all values of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="negative 1 is less than x, is less than 10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, if any, at which <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a critical point. Classify each critical point as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither. Justify your answers.
(b) Find the area of region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(c) Must there exist a value of <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0 less than c, less than 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>c</mi><mo><</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, such that <math alttext="g double prime of c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is equal to the average rate of change of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(d) Let <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, the integral from 0 to x squared, of, g of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="h prime of 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(e) The region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the base of a solid. For this solid, at each <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> the cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is a rectangle with height <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and base in the region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The volume of the solid is given by <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 9, of, A, of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an expression for <math alttext="A of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(f) What is the volume of the solid described in part (e)? Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(g) Evaluate <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 0, of, the fraction with numerator g of x, minus 5 x, plus 7, and denominator e to the x power, minus 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Give a reason for your answer.

(h) Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 9, of, the fraction with numerator g double prime of x, and denominator g prime of x, end fraction, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="true">∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> or show that it does not exist.

unit.text: 3: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
